p:
The strong progress in sequencing technologies is evident in the reduction in time and costs of human genome projects. The sequence of the 'inaugural human genomes' (3 × 10 9 bp), published in 2001 (refs. 26, 27, 28), was determined over a period of roughly 10 years at a cost of $3 billion—and it was incomplete
27 . In contrast, the complete sequence of Jim Watson's genome was determined in 4 months at a cost of less than $1 million
29 . Currently, the price has dropped further to below $50,000 (ref. 30), and there is reason to believe that the number of solved human sequences will exceed 1,000 in the near future.
